title: Technical Literacy Tiers VIBE Framework
summary: A 5-tier technical literacy gradient mapping how different audiences understand tech vocabulary, with practical application to the VIBE framework for progressive onboarding and communication strategies
key_points: Technical vocabulary falls on a 5-tier gradient from everyday language to engineering core
Most startup content assumes Tier 3 understanding, leaving Tier 2 users behind
VIBE framework (Vision, Interface, Backend, Execution) can be explained at different tier levels
Webhooks are Tier 4 concepts requiring dev-adjacent understanding
Progressive disclosure and tier-matched language enables better user onboarding
hooks: There's a hidden 'technical literacy gradient' that determines who understands your product
Most startup content assumes Tier 3 understanding - here's why that's a problem
How to explain the same concept at 5 different technical literacy levels
quotable_moments: Most startup or tech content assumes Tier 3 understanding. It drops terms like 'framework' or 'API' without explanation
CLI at Tier 4 - The acronym barrier is real. Even 'command line' feels intimidating
Instead of requiring people to climb from Tier 2 to Tier 4 before they can build anything meaningful, VIBE development lets them start where they are
review_notes: Exceptional framework for understanding technical communication barriers. The 5-tier system with concrete examples provides immediate practical value for product teams and educators. Webhook definition across tiers is particularly well done.
